bash.description: Bash is the go-to scripting language for automating tasks in Unix-like environments. Whether it's writing quick one-liners or full-fledged automation scripts, I often use Bash to streamline workflows and system administration tasks.

c.description: Few programming languages can claim to have influenced the software development landscape as much as C. To this day, C is still behind some of the biggest projects out there, such as the Linux kernel, and it is still unmatched in many embedded applications. C was my first programming language, and I appreciate the low-level control and efficiency that it gives you over your program.

cpp.description: C++ is the classic choice for object-oriented programming, offering high-level abstractions while retaining fine-grained memory control. It builds on C's foundations but expands possibilities with even more features.

git.description: Git is the top version control system, and for good reason: Git provides a simple and fast way to keep everyone in sync. All of my projects are hosted in Git, and I am highly comfortable using it.

github.description: GitHub is the primary platform that I use for hosting and collaborating on projects. With its powerful issue tracking, the pull request workflow, and easy CI/CD integrations via GitHub actions; it is with good reason that it leads the pack.

gitlab.description: GitLab is a powerful alternative to GitHub, especially for self-hosted repositories. I appreciate its built-in CI/CD tools, and have extensive experience using it when contributing to the GNOME project, who use GitLab to host all of their source code.

gtk.description: GTK is a cross-platform widget toolkit. It's written in C, but has language bindings to many other languages. It can be used by projects of any size, from one-off GUI control panels, to massive multi-application software suites. GTK is the GUI library used by the most popular Linux desktop environment, GNOME.

js.description: I primarily use vanilla JavaScript to enhance website interactivity, though I don't have experience with JS frameworks.

linux.description: I have made extensive use of Linux in many different contexts. For instance, on the server-side, I have done many hobbyist deployments of web applications on Linux-based VPS servers. On the desktop side, I have used Debian Linux as my sole desktop operating system for the past several years.

php.description: PHP might not be the trendiest language anymore. However, when it comes to providing a method to inject some basic server-side functionality into an otherwise static web page, it is unmatched. While I wouldn't choose it for large projects today, its ease of use makes it ideal for simple web applications.

python.description: Python is perhaps the most versatile tool at a modern programmer's disposal. With a simple, straight-forward syntax, friendly community, and libraries for nearly everything, Python leads the pack when it comes to scripting languages. I often prefer to use Python more on the development side rather than for end-user applications, though I have experience with both.

sql.description: SQL is a time-tested tool for interacting with databases. Though no-SQL databases are often talked about, SQL's compatibility is unmatched. I have used MySQL, Oracle 10g, and PostgreSQL in the past.

rust.description: Rust stands out for its memory safety, achieved without a garbage collector thanks to its unique ownership model and compile-time checks. When I need low-level performance, I often reach for Rust, because it is nice that I don't have to roll my own data structures like I might have to do in a language like C.
